metadata.title: Atypical COVID -19 presentation in patient undergoing staged TAAA repair

body_text.text: A 65 year old man was referred to the vascular department for an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6 cm on ultrasound. The patient had an extensive medical history of hypertension, coronary artery disease with previous myocardial infraction and stenting, previous stroke without residual deficit, stable Crohn’s disease (managed by azathioprine treatment), hypothyroidism and gout. He also suffered from chronic lower back and hip pain occurring after 500 meters of walking. He had palpable pulses in the femoral and dorsalis pedis arteries bilaterally with an ankle brachial index (ABI) of 0.86 right and 0.82 left. 10 years previously he had also severe hypertension and left renal artery stenosis, which then was treated with a renal stent, creatinine at admission was normal.

Due to the patient’s multiple comorbidities he was considered unsuitable for open TAAA repair. He was found anatomically suitable for an endovascular repair with a 4 fenestrated endovascular graft. There was some question as to the caliber and suitability of the iliac access vessels and there was also a high risk for distal thrombus embolization from the shaggy descending thoracic aorta. To minimize the risk of spinal cord ischemia (SCI) and to evaluate and optimize the iliac access, the procedure was planned for 2 stages with a 4-6-week interval for recovery and development of collateral pathways to the spinal cord.

The patient underwent stage 1, percutaneous thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) with placement of a thoracic stent-graft from the left subclavian artery to 4 cm proximal to the celiac artery origin (Fig 3
). The patient was observed in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a SCI protocol for 36 hours postoperatively and was then observed an additional24 hours in the vascular department before discharge to home. At discharge, ABI was unchanged and Creatinine normal. The patient was scheduled for the second stage procedure after 4-6 weeks with final exclusion of the aneurysm with a fenestrated stent-graft.

Ten days after discharge the patient returned emergently to the outpatient clinic with complaints of leg pain on exertion bilaterally. No pain at rest. He also describes vertigo on postural changes and that his legs feel weak and “give way” after 25meters of walking. The symptoms had started 2-3 days after discharge and for the last two days he also described diarrhea twice daily. No fevers, chills or nausea. On physical exam the patient was somewhat ashy in appearance. Abdomen was soft and non-tender. Foot pulses and ABI’s were unchanged and there were no signs of lower limb weakness or sensory loss.
Patient was admitted with cultures of urine and feces. Laboratory tests were normal except a CRP of 53. No fever on admission.

On a low grade suspicion of spinal cord ischemia (due to loss of control of his legs) and/or thrombus embolism to the internal iliac arteries, causing buttock claudication, the patient underwent CTA. The scan was unremarkable showing a well-positioned TEVAR graft, patent visceral and iliac arteries. A neurology consult found no clinical indication of SCI. An MR scan of the medulla was performed to exclude ischemia and findings were normal.

The patient was isolated on admission due to his diarrhea. On day two, he persisted to have pain on exertion and developed a temperature of 38,1C. As no explanation was found for his complaints and considering the current Corona pandemic, a Covid19 test was performed. This was positive. The patient was subsequently moved to the infectious disease department for further care. Here he developed increasing respiratory symptoms and CRP elevation to 154. He was treated with oxygen supplementation and respiratory therapy without need for further ventilator support. The patient was discharged to home after 9 days in good clinical condition.

Patients contacts were traced and questioned for symptoms. However, testing was not performed on asymptomatic individuals at that time. As the patient was isolated on submission due to GI disease, the patient was isolated before he was tested for Covid and staff used gown, gloves and mask when in contact with him.

The typical and most common presentation of COVID 19 is that of upper respiratory tract infection with fever, cough and respiratory distress (7). Symptoms vary from very mild to very severe and the incubation period is 2-14 days, with increasing symptoms over time. However, as in the current case, Covid 19 can also present in an atypical fashion clouding diagnosis particularly in the setting of concurrent diseases or treatments.

Endovascular thoraco-abdominal aortic aneurysm repair is a procedure that carries a significant risk of spinal cord ischemia due to blockage of critical collateral supply to the spinal cord during the procedure (1). The more anatomically extensive the repair is, the higher the risk. Patients that have shaggy aorta (aortic intra luminal wall thrombus) seem to be at even higher risk due to athero-embolic embolization peri-procedurally (2). In addition, complications leading to drop in blood pressure in the perioperative period are also considered aggravating factors. These can consist of perioperative bleeding complications often connected to poor iliac access (narrow iliac diameter preventing stent graft delivery). Due to these risks, if possible, a staged approach is recommended for elective TAAA repair (3, 4). This allows both for collateral network mobilization to the SC and avoids some risks of perioperative bleeding complications occurring in the same setting as a complete elective TAAA repair (5, 6).

In the current case, the patient presented with symptoms of buttock claudication and leg weakness, as in a Leriche syndrome (pain, fatigue, or cramping in the legs and buttocks, pale and cold legs, and erectile dysfunction due to aorto-iliac occlusion), or of delayed onset SCI with lower extremity weakness which has been described after endovascular TAAA repair. His gastrointestinal symptoms were difficult to interpret in the setting of his diagnosis of Crohn’s disease as well. The patient had no signs of URTI on admission and it did indeed take several days after his admission, and further days since his onset of symptoms, before he developed more classical signs and symptoms of Covid 19 such as fever and respiratory distress. Given the timing of Covid -19 infection, it cannot be ruled out that the illness was acquired during the first hospitalization. At that stage of the pandemic, no routine testing of asymptomatic patients was performed. However, the incidence of Covid-19 was low in Denmark at the time and the prevalcence in the hospital was equally low. Staff were required to stay home if they displayed minimal signs of URTI.

The present case has not changed the staging policy or staging duration at the department. This is due to the fact that overall, the threshold for aneurysm repair at this time has been raised to 7cm. In addition, at the present time, all patients admitted to the hospital for overnight stay are tested for corona virus. Given the coagulopathy associated with Covid 19, inflammatory markers including CRP will be re-checked before proceeding with stage two of the repair.

In conclusion, in the current setting of a global corona virus pandemic, patients presenting with atypical signs and symptoms and admitted to a hospital should undergo liberal testing for Covid 19 to prevent disease transmission to patients and staff . Until results are known, isolation and protective measures should be taken.

FIGREF0.text: Fig 1: large throacoabdominal aneurysm (a) extending from mid thoracic aorta to infrarenal aorta (b)

FIGREF1.text: Fig 2: Mid descending aorta displaying large amounts of intraluminal thrombus.

FIGREF2.text: Fig 3: CTA showing TEVAR graft placed from mid descending thoracic aorta to supra-celiac position. Preserved flow to visceral and iliac arteries.
